ResponsesInList.Title: Global timeout even though maxtime was not even nearly obtained
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello. I am teaching a basic programming course and I use VPL for my evaluations. Most questions are fairly simple and can be solved in a few miliseconds, so I randomly create 100 test cases and assign a grade according to how many of them are correctly solved. Most questions take one or two seconds to be graded in this manner (or at least this is how long it takes after I click on the "evaluate" button). However, the "Maximum execution time" is not respected. Here's a MRE: There are 128 test cases, all equal to Case = Test input = 1 output = 1 Solution (in C) is #include <stdio.h> int main() { printf("1"); return 0; } It takes about 2 seconds to compile and 1 to evaluate, when it works. Maximum memory is 512MB, maximum execution files 128MB and maximum processes is 10. When I set up Maximum execution time to 8 minutes or more, it evaluates as above; However, anything below that yields "Global timeout". Some VPLs which I created evaluate in 4 minutes, others 2. I couldn't find a pattern. IT in my uni noticed that vpl_evaluate.cpp ( https://vpl.dis.ulpgc.es/releases/vpl_evaluate.cpp ) has these lines: int timeout = maxtime / testCases.size(); for (size_t i = 0; i < testCases.size(); i++) { //... if (timeout <= 1 || Timer::elapsedTime() >= maxtime) { //... addFatalError("Global timeout"); and that maxtime = maximum time in seconds (integer). So if maxtime < testCases.size() we automatically get a "Global timeout" error, and this might be related to this issue. However, it does not explain why it does not evaluate in 4 minutes. So, I always have to set up a relatively high maximum execution time in order for correct answers to be properly evaluated (4 or 8 minutes, usually), even if they are actually evaluated basically instantly. However, whenever a student makes a nonending loop, they have to way for that whole time (4+ minutes) in order to get the timeout error message and be able to try again. This hinders VPLs usability in exams, which are time-sensitive. Is there anything I can do to mitigate this problem as a professor (no access to uni server and moodle plugin configs)? Or is there anything I could indicate IT to do? I note that this problem was already noticed in https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=451871&lang=en . Thank you very much.

ResponsesInList.Title: Global timeout even though maxtime was not even nearly obtained
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Luiz, Thank you for reporting this issue, and sorry for the inconvenience you‚Äôre experiencing. You are correct ‚Äî the BIOTES evaluator represents time limits as integer seconds and distributes the total maximum execution time among all test cases. Specifically, the timeout for each case is calculated approximately as: `timeout_per_case = maxtime / number_of_cases` Because of this design, if the number of test cases is large and the total time limit is not proportionally higher, the timeout for each individual case may become too small, causing a ‚ÄúGlobal timeout‚Äù error even when the total execution time seems reasonable. To avoid this, you should ensure that the maximum execution time is greater than the number of test cases . The more test cases you have, the larger this global time limit needs to be. Better Solution: Use the GIOTES Evaluator This limitation has been resolved in the newer GIOTES evaluator (VPL version >= 4.3.0), which is mostly compatible with BIOTES but provides much more flexibility in timeout management. With GIOTES , you can: Define a default timeout per test case using "time limit=" before any case, Override the timeout for specific cases using "time limit=" in the case, and Use floating-point values for more precise time limits (e.g., 0.5 seconds). This allows you to manage large numbers of test cases efficiently without artificially inflating the total maximum time. Server Configuration Note Be aware that the jail server configuration can also limit the maximum execution time.
By default, the jail server‚Äôs global timeout is 1800 seconds (30 minutes) , but this can be freely adjusted by the jail server administrator. In most cases, the default settings work well. However, reducing the number of allowed processes too much can negatively affect performance and lead to unexpected timeouts, so I would recommend keeping the default or slightly increasing it rather than lowering it. Best regards

Extensive testing is required to fully understand the workflow. Process execution limits should be suitable for the proposed workload. When VPL tries to locate an available execution server for your request, it checks whether each server has enough free memory to satisfy the maximum memory limit defined in the activity configuration. If the required memory exceeds either the maximum memory allowed in the Jail Server configuration or the currently available free memory on that server, the request will not be assigned to that server. To resolve this issue, please verify: The maximum memory limit configured for each request in your Jail Server setup:
üîó Jail Server configuration ‚Äì maxMemory The maximum memory used in the activity configuration:
üîó Activity configuration ‚Äì execution resource limits If the activity‚Äôs requested memory is higher than what each Jail Server allows or what‚Äôs currently available, the system will report ‚Äúno execution server found.‚Äù

ResponsesInList.Text:
Dear Amit Singh, After a examination of the issue you've described, it appears the cause is linked to the configuration of the NODE_PATH environment variable. This variable allows Node.js to locate global modules, including the `readline-sync` module your script depends on. To address this problem and ensure your JavaScript code executes in VPL, a temporary solution can be implemented until the upcoming VPL release, which will include an automatic configuration of the NODE_PATH variable. Here is an enhanced script for your `vpl_run.sh` file. This script sets up the NODE_PATH variable and prepare the run of your JavaScript code. 
```text
#!/bin/bash
# This file is part of VPL for Moodle - 
http://vpl.dis.ulpgc.es/

# Script for JavaScript language using NodeJs
# Copyright (C) 2024 Juan Carlos Rodr√≠guez-del-Pino
# License 
http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/gpl.html
 GNU GPL v3 or later
# Author Juan Carlos Rodr√≠guez-del-Pino <jcrodriguez@dis.ulpgc.es>

. common_script.sh
check_program nodejs
if [ "$1" == "version" ] ; then

fi

cat common_script.sh > vpl_execution
[ "$(command -pv npm)" != "" ] && (echo "export NODE_PATH=$(npm root -g)" >> vpl_execution)
echo "nodejs \"$FIRST_SOURCE_FILE\" \$@" >> vpl_execution
chmod +x vpl_execution
```
 Please apply this script in the "Execution files" of your VPL activity and let us know if you encounter any further issues. This workaround should serve well until the next VPL release. Best regards,

ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Giuseppe, Thanks for your message. I understand that when you mention "I have set VPL to listen on port 8443 HTTPS and 8080 HTTP", you are referring to the VPL Jail System . Just to clarify, installing the VPL Jail System on a VPS is not the most typical setup. If accessing `http://server:8282/OK` returns ‚ÄúOK‚Äù, then the VPL Jail System is likely running correctly. However, there may be a small typo: based on your earlier message, I believe the correct port should be `8080` , not `8282` . Assuming your Moodle site is using the default ports (80 for HTTP and 443 for HTTPS), here are a few key points and recommendations to help you troubleshoot the timeout issue: Checklist to verify configuration Verify the ports Double-check the port numbers you‚Äôve configured, both in the VPL Jail System and in the Moodle VPL plugin. Use full external URL In the Moodle VPL plugin configuration, ensure you're using the full external URL (e.g., `https://your-domain:8443` ). Do not use `localhost` here, note that this URL is send to the browser to access the VPL-Jail-System. Check HTTPS functionality Make sure you can access `https://your-domain:8443/OK` . This will confirm that the VPL Jail System is properly serving over HTTPS. URLPATH security It is highly recommended to configure the `URLPATH` parameter in the VPL Jail System. This adds a layer of security by ensuring only authorized Moodle servers can access it. Self-signed certificate setting Since you are using a valid Let's Encrypt certificate, the "accept self-signed certificates" option in the Moodle plugin should be disabled . Reverse proxy and WebSocket support If you're using a reverse proxy to expose the VPL Jail System, ensure it supports WebSocket connections . Note that the `/OK` endpoint does not use WebSockets, so its success does not guarantee that task execution will work properly. Remove unnecessary HTTP port If you're not using HTTP on port 8080, consider disabling it to reduce attack surface and potential misconfiguration. ResponsesInList.Title: Protecting VPL Servers
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there really no way to prevent external access for VPL Servers? It seems awfully short sighted to allow arbitrary code execution open to the entire internet. Short of whitelisting VPL Users at an external firewall is there really no easy way to secure this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Protecting VPL Servers
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Jacob, to secure VPL execution servers and prevent external access, you can: Use HTTPS with the appropriate certificates. Configure the `URLPATH` parameter in the execution servers. This acts as a secret key only known to the administrator, ensuring that only requests with the correct `URLPATH` are served. Set the `TASK_ONLY_FROM` parameter, which allows you to define a whitelist of IP addresses without relying on an external firewall. You can find detailed instructions on implementing these security measures at VPL Documentation - Security Parameters .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Protecting VPL Servers
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Jacob, The `URLPATH` configuration parameter is solely utilized during the execution task requests between the Moodle server and the execution server. This ‚Äúpassword‚Äù is neither required nor accessible from the user's browser in any form. Communication between the user's browser and the execution server is protected through single-use tickets generated by the execution server for each execution. The concerns about data leakage from browser plugins or indexers do not apply to URLPATH, as it is never exposed outside the server-to-server communication. It is important to base security discussions on a clear understanding of how these mechanisms work. If you have further technical questions or need clarifications, feel free to reach out. Best regards, Juan Carlos

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Protecting VPL Servers
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't see a clear advantage in using separate ports for task requests and WebSocket connections. WebSocket connections are secured using HTTPS and switch to WebSocket protocols, ensuring robust encryption. Additionally, many organizations aim to minimize the number of open ports to streamline security management. Regarding your concern about system administrators potentially being unaware of the risks of omitting the `URLPATH` parameter, future releases of VPL will address this. We will introduce warnings in the execution server startup process and in the VPL plugin's execution server checks. These warnings will explicitly highlight the risks of not using `URLPATH` and strongly recommend its configuration to enhance security.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: VPL Docker Containers - Setup
ResponsesInList.Text: Dr. S. Rajasekaran, Thank you for sharing your experience with VPL. Details are important for understanding the behavior and performance of VPL. Could you please indicate if you have tested adding more Jail servers to your Moodle server to resolve the performance issues and what resources (especially RAM) the machines you added have available? Using one machine for both the Moodle server and the Jail Server may raise some inconveniences. You must limit the resources available for the Jail Server to avoid slowing down Moodle when the jail server gets very bussy. From your statement, ‚ÄúI tried to run Moodle and VPL containers on the same machine and connect with Docker network,‚Äù I understand that you are trying to expose only the Moodle server to the internet. Note that, as indicated in the manual, the Jail Server must also be exposed to the internet (see the third requirement). Documentation on VPL Jail System Requirements To run both servers on the same machine, you may use two names or different ports for the same machine. The first approach requires proper configuration of a reverse proxy using Nginx or Apache , for example. Remember to set the correct URL (reachable from the internet) for the jail server in the VPL plugin configuration. Note that if you use localhost or the localhost IP (127.X:X:X) for your jail server it will only be available from a browser on that machine. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Use VPL with large files
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Nicolas BODIN, I appreciate your interest in using VPL (Virtual Programming Lab) for your algorithms and abstract data types course. Thank you for bringing up your concerns regarding the page load speed and file saving behavior. I'd like to address each point: Slow Page Load for Showing Large Files: The delay you are experiencing is due to the system is interpreting unknown file types as code files, thus attempting to render them. Solution for Slow Page Load: To circumvent this issue, you can rename the files with a .bin extension. This will mark the files as binary, and the description page and editor will not attempt to display their content. To add these .bin files to the editor, you can use the drag-and-drop feature or the import functionality. Required vs. Execution Files: You don't necessarily need to add these large files to the "Required files" section. Adding them to the "Execution files" section and marking them as "Files to keep when running" will suffice for your purposes. File Saving Behavior: The editor, by design, saves all the files every time you execute a save command, regardless of whether a single file or multiple files have been modified. I hope this addresses your concerns and assists you in efficiently using VPL for your educational needs. If you have further questions or require additional clarification, please do not hesitate to reach out. Best regards, Juan Carlos

ResponsesInList.Text:
Recently I have a similar issue on running OpenGL program in VPL and I would like to contribute my experimental solution. The workaround is to run the nested X server "Xephyr" and display the vpl_wexecution program to the nested window. Below is the steps for preparing the jail server: Install Xephyr (apt install xserver-xephyr) Modify /usr/sbin/vpl/vpl_vnc_launcher.sh, replace the line "$HOME/vpl_wexecution &> .std_output" with the following block 
```text
        if [ -f $HOME/.glx_required ]; then
          VNCDISPLAY=$(ls $HOME/.vnc/*.log | sed -e "s/[^:]*://" -e "s/\.log$//")
          XEPHYRDISP=$(($VNCDISPLAY+25000))
          Xephyr :$XEPHYRDISP -fullscreen &
          while true; do
            DISPLAY=:$XEPHYRDISP xdpyinfo >& /dev/null
            [ "$?" == "0" ] && break
          done
          DISPLAY=:$XEPHYRDISP $HOME/vpl_wexecution &> .std_output
        else
          $HOME/vpl_wexecution &> .std_output
        fi
```
 For a VPL instance that requires GLX support In "Execution files" section, add an empty file called .glx_required In "Files to keep when running" section, tick .glx_required In "Resources limits", the option "Maximum memory used" should be at least 256MB In fact, the workaround is a preliminary work. It has been tested in single-user case (at least for my programs). I am not sure whether it works without trouble in multi-user case. Hope this would help in your case.

ResponsesInList.Text:
It looks like I found a partial solution to my problem. Not sure about its safety, but seems to be working. The trick is to modify and recompile the vpl daemon C++ code so the user GID is always the same (2000 in my case). Technically no secondary group, but I get the group membership I need. Won't work if several groups per prisoner are needed. Procedure: Do all the steps on the installation page until this step . Stop before executing `install-script-sh` . OR simply `cd` to your `vpl-jail-system-[version]` directory you used for vpl jail installation. Find the following line: link `src/processMonitor.cpp` file `processMonitor::becomePrisoner(int prisoner)` method `setresgid` function ( `unistd.h` ) Modify the line: `if (setresgid(prisoner, prisoner, prisoner)!= 0) {` After modification (hard-coded gid=2000 in my case): `if (setresgid(2000, 2000, 2000)!= 0) {` Stop the daemon and backup config if you made any customizations: `sudo systemctl stop vpl-jail-system.service` `sudo systemctl disable vpl-jail-system.service` `` `sudo mv /usr/sbin/vpl /usr/sbin/vpl.backup` `sudo cp /etc/vpl/ /etc/vpl.backup` `sudo cp /etc/vpl/vpl-jail-system.conf /etc/vpl/vpl-jail-system.conf.backup` Re-run installation script in order to recompile the daemon (respond "no" to software & SSL key installation queries if you have them already installed): `sudo ./install-vpl-sh` Edit `/usr/sbin/vpl/vpl-jail-system` (fresh one was copied from `vpl-jail-system.initd` during the previous step). Diff is here: https://diffonline.net/1JZPOA982x Before: 
```text
function set_etc {
        #passwd file
        local PASSWORDFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/passwd"
        local I
        echo "root:*:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash" > "$PASSWORDFILE"
        for (( I=$MIN_PRISONER_UGID ; $I < $MAX_PRISONER_UGID ; I+=1 )) ; do
                echo "p$I:*:$I:$I:prisoner $I:/home/p$I:/bin/bash" >> "$PASSWORDFILE"
        done
        chmod 644 "$PASSWORDFILE"
        #group file
        local GROUPFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/group"
        echo "root:*:0:root" > "$GROUPFILE"
        for (( I=$MIN_PRISONER_UGID ; $I < $MAX_PRISONER_UGID ; I+=1 )) ; do
                echo "p$I:*:$I:p$I" >> "$GROUPFILE"
        done
        chmod 644 "$GROUPFILE"
        local SHADOWFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/shadow"
        chown root.root "$SHADOWFILE"
        chmod 600 "$SHADOWFILE"
}
```
 After (replace `mygroup` and `2000` as needed): 
```text
function set_etc {
        local MYGROUP="mygroup"
        local MYGROUPGUID="2000"
        #passwd file
        local PASSWORDFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/passwd"
        local I
        echo "root:*:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash" > "$PASSWORDFILE"
        for (( I=$MIN_PRISONER_UGID ; $I < $MAX_PRISONER_UGID ; I+=1 )) ; do
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  No execution server available: - Error after various upgrades
ResponsesInList.Text: Notice that in the "Check execution servers" there is a column "Last error info" and another "Last error date". The execution server rejects a task if the memory requested is greater than the memory available in the server or greater than the MAXMEMORY parameter value (set in the execution server configuration). To avoid the problem, the "Maximum memory used" parameter in the site administration vpl plugin must be set to a value equal or lower than the MAXMEMORY in the execution server configuration and the available memory in your execution server. The line with "Memory requested 2097152000" shows a strange number of bytes. It seems that your installation has a very high "Maximum default memory used" value (site administration vpl plugin setting) and a low MAXMEMORY in the execution server configuration. Best regards, Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, Is there a way to have more that one VPL server to serve the users for load balancing and redundancy ? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Clustering VPL server
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not an expert in load balancing configuration but I think that with the network architecture of VPL it may be difficult to use an "execution server" load balancer. Notice that the execution process takes different steps and requires different network connections that need to be established with the same server in the cluster. For example, the evaluation process takes these steps. 1) A user launches an evaluation process. e.g. the user clicks evaluate button. 2) The browser sends a request ( AJAX / JSON ) to the Moodle server. 3) The Moodle server selects an execution server (with retries) and sends the task to an execution server (HTTP/XMLRPC). The execution server generates different security tokens as a response to de request. The task start. 4) The Moodle server responds to the Browser request with information with the "execution server URL " and the security tokens. 5) The browser connects with the execution server using the URL+security token and the "WebSocket" protocol to monitor the task. 6) When the task end, the monitor sends a request (AJAX/JSON) to the Moodle server to retrieve the task report/result. 8) The Moodle server request the "execution server" the task result (HTTP/XMLRPC) with the security token, save it and return the result to the browser. 9) The browser shows the result.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How does the vpl plugin handle two Jail Servers?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Douglas, The system splits tasks between the servers. For each task, the selection of the execution server is as follow 1) If there are servers online then one is preselected randomly. If a server was marked offline 5 or more minutes ago, it's considered already online for this preselection. 1.1) If the preselected server is found offline the server is marked as offline and repeats step 1. If the preselected server is found overloaded repeats step 1. 2) If all online servers have been preselected then all servers, online or not, are sequentially preselected again. 3) If no server can be selected a message is shown to the user. - Notice that after preselecting a server, it is checked to know if it is or not online and if it is overloaded.
